title.value: GAUCHE: A Library for Gaussian Processes in Chemistry
title.justification: Extracted directly from the title of the paper.
title.quote: GAUCHE: A Library for Gaussian Processes in Chemistry

extractions.description: The paper introduces GAUCHE, an open-source library designed for applying Gaussian processes to chemistry problems. It is particularly useful in low-data regimes and focuses on applications such as molecular discovery, reaction optimization, and protein design. GAUCHE offers a range of GPU-accelerated kernels designed to handle molecular representations like graphs, strings, and bit vectors. The library interfaces with GPyTorch and BoTorch and aims to make probabilistic modeling and black-box optimization techniques accessible to chemists and materials scientists.

type.justification: The paper includes experimental results such as the evaluation of models on regression, uncertainty quantification, and Bayesian optimization tasks, thereby demonstrating empirical results.
type.quote: We evaluate GAUCHE on a range of regression, uncertainty quantification (UQ) and Bayesian optimisation (BO) tasks.

name.justification: The paper discusses the application of machine learning models, particularly Gaussian processes, to problems in chemistry such as molecular discovery and reaction optimization.
name.quote: In molecular discovery campaigns, we are typically interested in solving problems of the form x⋆ = arg max f(x), x ∈ X where f(·) : X → R is an expensive black-box function over a structured input domain X.

name.justification: The paper focuses on applying Gaussian processes to various chemical problems and offers a library of Gaussian process models optimized for chemistry applications.
name.quote: We introduce GAUCHE, an open-source library for GAUssian processes in CHEmistry.

name.justification: The paper involves the use of Bayesian optimization methods, especially in the context of molecular discovery and reaction optimization, which are major applications discussed.
name.quote: Bayesian optimisation (BO) [32, 33, 34, 35, 29, 36] is a data-efficient methodology for determining x⋆ .

name.justification: The paper evaluates GAUCHE on uncertainty quantification tasks, indicating that uncertainty quantification is a significant aspect of the research.
name.quote: The principle goal in conducting regression and UQ benchmarks is to gauge whether performance on these tasks may be used as a proxy for BO performance.

name.justification: The paper delves deeply into various molecular representations such as graphs, strings, and fingerprints, which are crucial for applying machine learning techniques in chemistry.
name.quote: We review commonly used representations for molecules (Section 3.1), chemical reactions (Section 3.2) and proteins (Section 3.3), before describing the kernels that operate on them in Section 4.

name.justification: The paper includes specific sections and implementations related to graph kernels, particularly in the context of Gaussian processes applied to molecular graphs.
name.quote: Graph kernels define a mapping ϕλ : G → H from a graph domain G to a feature space H, in which the inner product between a pair of graphs g, g ′ ∈ G serves as a similarity measure kGraph (g, g ′ ) := σf 2 · ⟨ϕλ (g), ϕλ (g ′ )⟩H , where λ denotes kernel-specific hyperparameters.

name.justification: The Tanimoto Kernel GP Model is frequently mentioned throughout the paper and is evaluated in multiple experiments.
name.quote: We subsequently train a Tanimoto kernel GP on the featurisation. The results are provided in Table 6 and indicate that the GP model obtains low generalisation error on the melting point prediction task.

is_contributed.justification: The Tanimoto-Kernel GP model is a well-known model used in the paper but not contributed by the paper itself.
is_contributed.quote: We subsequently train a Tanimoto kernel GP on the featurisation. The results are provided in Table 6 and indicate that the GP model obtains low generalisation error on the melting point prediction task.

is_executed.justification: The Tanimoto-Kernel GP model was executed on GPU in the experiments as mentioned in the paper.
is_executed.quote: GAUCHE provides a modular, robust and easy-to-use framework to rapidly prototype GP S with 30+ GPU-accelerated string, fingerprint and graph kernels...

is_compared.justification: The Tanimoto-Kernel GP model was compared to other models like deep Bayesian models, as indicated by the experimental results presented in the paper.
is_compared.quote: Summarising our results in Table 1, we find that Tanimoto-based GPs generally outperform Scalar Product ones in terms of RMSD and NLDP, while string kernel-based GP S often yield even better performance.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No specific referenced paper title provided in the main text for Tanimoto Kernel GP model.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Summarising our results in Table 1, we find that Tanimoto-based GPs generally outperform Scalar Product ones in terms of RMSD and NLDP, while string kernel-based GP S often yield even better performance.

name.justification: The SMILES String Kernel GP Model is described in detail and its implementation is provided in the paper.
name.quote: we implement the SMILES string kernel [54] which calculates an inner product between the occurrences of sub-strings, considering all contiguous sub-strings made from at most n characters (we set n = 5 in our experiments).

is_contributed.justification: The SMILES String Kernel GP model is not a new contribution by the authors but is implemented and used in their experiments.
is_contributed.quote: we implement the SMILES string kernel [54] which calculates an inner product between the occurrences of sub-strings, considering all contiguous sub-strings made from at most n characters (we set n = 5 in our experiments).

is_executed.justification: The SMILES String Kernel GP model was executed on GPU in the experiments as described in the paper.
is_executed.quote: GAUCHE provides a modular, robust and easy-to-use framework to rapidly prototype GP S with 30+ GPU-accelerated string, fingerprint and graph kernels...

is_compared.justification: The SMILES String Kernel GP model was compared to other models like Tanimoto-Kernel GP in various tasks as shown in the results section.
is_compared.quote: Summarising our results in Table 1, we find that Tanimoto-based GPs generally outperform Scalar Product ones in terms of RMSD and NLDP, while string kernel-based GP S often yield even better performance.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No specific referenced paper title provided in the main text for SMILES String Kernel GP model.
referenced_paper_title.quote: we implement the SMILES string kernel [54] which calculates an inner product between the occurrences of sub-strings, considering all contiguous sub-strings made from at most n characters (we set n = 5 in our experiments).

name.justification: The WL Kernel GP Model is used for comparing different graph-based Gaussian Process techniques in the paper.
name.quote: The Weisfeiler-Lehman (WL) kernel [57], for instance, is given by the inner products of label count vectors over λ iterations of the Weisfeiler-Lehman algorithm [58].

is_contributed.justification: The WL Kernel GP model is not contributed by this paper but is a standard model used for graph-based GP tasks.
is_contributed.quote: The Weisfeiler-Lehman (WL) kernel [57], for instance, is given by the inner products of label count vectors over λ iterations of the Weisfeiler-Lehman algorithm [58].

is_executed.justification: The WL Kernel GP model was executed on GPU in the experiments as described in the paper.
is_executed.quote: GAUCHE provides a modular, robust and easy-to-use framework to rapidly prototype GP S with 30+ GPU-accelerated string, fingerprint and graph kernels...

is_compared.justification: The WL Kernel GP Model was explicitly compared with other models based on different molecular representations in the empirical study.
is_compared.quote: Summarising our results in Table 1, we find that Tanimoto-based GPs generally outperform Scalar Product ones in terms of RMSD and NLDP, while string kernel-based GP S often yield even better performance.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No specific referenced paper title provided in the main text for WL Kernel GP model.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Weisfeiler-Lehman (WL) kernel [57], for instance, is given by the inner products of label count vectors over λ iterations of the Weisfeiler-Lehman algorithm [58].

name.justification: The Photoswitch Dataset is explicitly mentioned as one of the datasets used for evaluating models in the paper.
name.quote: Photoswitch The labels y are the values of the E isomer π − π ∗ transition wavelength for 392 photoswitch molecules [3].

referenced_paper_title.value: Data-driven discovery of molecular photoswitches with multioutput Gaussian processes

referenced_paper_title.quote: Photoswitch The labels y are the values of the E isomer π − π ∗ transition wavelength for 392 photoswitch molecules [3].

name.justification: The ESOL dataset is used for benchmarking the regression and Bayesian optimization tasks in the paper.
name.quote: ESOL The labels y are the logarithmic aqueous solubility values for 1128 organic small molecules [60].

name.justification: GAUCHE is the primary library introduced and discussed in the paper. It provides Gaussian Processes capabilities for chemical applications.
name.quote: We introduce GAUCHE, an open-source library for GAUssian processes in CHEmistry.

referenced_paper_title.justification: GAUCHE is the main contribution of the paper itself.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We introduce GAUCHE, an open-source library for GAUssian processes in CHEmistry.

name.justification: GAUCHE interfaces with the GPyTorch library for Gaussian Process models.
name.quote: Furthermore, GAUCHE interfaces with the GPyTorch [26] and BoTorch [27] libraries
